caseTitle: SOCIETY LTD, ACCRA. v. THE GHANA PRIVATE ROAD TRANSPORT
summary: This Court of Appeal decision in Ghana arose from a dispute between Kaneshie/Cape Coast/Takoradi Co-operative Transport Society Ltd and the Ghana Private Road Transport Union (GPRTU) over control and loading rights at Kaneshie Lorry Station. The High Court had previously issued an order on December 11, 1997, requiring compliance with loading rules and permitting both parties' vehicles to operate under an Interim Management Committee. When the respondent union alleged violations, they filed a motion for interim injunction seeking enforcement. Instead of enforcing the existing order, the trial judge imposed a 'compromise ruling' appointing the Chief Labour Officer to supervise operationsâ€”a remedy not requested by either party. The Court of Appeal unanimously allowed the appeal, holding that the trial judge exceeded his authority by introducing an order inconsistent with the relief sought, effectively creating a new case not presented by the parties. The appellate court emphasized that enforcement applications must uphold, not alter, existing orders, and that judicial discretion does not permit such unilateral changes. The impugned order was set aside, and the matter remitted for fresh hearing before a different judge to determine compliance with the original injunction.
verdict: Appeal allowed; impugned compromise order set aside and matter remitted for fresh hearing before a different judge.
winningSide: Appellant (Kaneshie/Cape Coast/Takoradi Co-operative Transport Society Ltd)
rationaleHighlights: The trial judge erred by introducing a 'compromise order' not sought by either party, thereby altering the effect of an existing court order.
An application for enforcement of a court order should not be used to vary or undermine that order.
The principle in Adjei vrs: Foriwaa does not permit courts to make orders inconsistent with the relief sought.
The appeal court emphasized that parties are entitled to have their cases decided on the basis of their pleadings, not a court-imposed alternative.
The failure to investigate competing claims before making a new order constituted a procedural injustice.
The proper remedy was to set aside the impugned order and remit the matter for hearing before a different judge.
Contempt proceedings were relevant where a party allegedly violated a court order, rather than a fresh injunction application.
Judicial discretion in equitable matters must align with the nature and scope of the application before the court.
